content.title: Peripheral Neuropathy
content.summary: Peripheral neuropathy is dysfunction of peripheral nerves causing sensory, motor, and/or autonomic symptoms. It is classified by fiber type (large vs small fiber), distribution (length-dependent vs non-length-dependent), pathology (axonal vs demyelinating), and etiology. Diabetes is the most common cause; systematic workup identifies treatable causes.
key_points: Diabetes and prediabetes account for ~50% of cases
Distinguish axonal (gradual, distal weakness) from demyelinating (proximal, areflexia) on NCS/EMG
Small fiber neuropathy: burning pain, autonomic symptoms; normal NCS; diagnose by skin biopsy
Initial workup: glucose, HbA1c, B12, TSH, SPEP; expand based on clinical suspicion
Treat underlying cause; neuropathic pain responds to gabapentinoids, TCAs, SNRIs
content.statement: Peripheral neuropathy is a disorder of peripheral nerves classified by distribution, fiber type, pathophysiology, and etiology, with diabetes being the most common cause, requiring systematic evaluation to identify treatable conditions and appropriate symptomatic management.

explanation.intuition: Peripheral nerves are like the wiring connecting your brain to your body. When this wiring is damaged, signals get scrambled - you might feel numbness, tingling, burning, or weakness. The 'stocking-glove' pattern occurs because the longest nerves (going to feet/hands) are most vulnerable.
explanation.key_insight: The NCS/EMG distinction between axonal and demyelinating neuropathy is crucial: axonal (reduced amplitudes, normal velocities) suggests toxic/metabolic causes, while demyelinating (slow velocities, conduction block) suggests inflammatory or hereditary causes that may be treatable.
explanation.technical_details: Large fiber neuropathy affects Aα (proprioception) and Aβ (touch) fibers causing numbness, imbalance, and areflexia. Small fiber neuropathy affects Aδ (cold, sharp pain) and C fibers (warm, dull pain, autonomic) causing burning dysesthesias and autonomic dysfunction with normal NCS.

definitions_glossary.peripheral_neuropathy: Dysfunction of peripheral nerves causing sensory, motor, or autonomic symptoms
definitions_glossary.polyneuropathy: Symmetric, diffuse peripheral nerve involvement (vs mononeuropathy)
definitions_glossary.length_dependent: Symptoms start distally and progress proximally (stocking-glove pattern)
definitions_glossary.axonal_neuropathy: Primary damage to nerve axon; NCS shows reduced amplitudes
definitions_glossary.demyelinating_neuropathy: Primary damage to myelin sheath; NCS shows slowed conduction
definitions_glossary.small_fiber_neuropathy: Selective damage to unmyelinated C-fibers and small myelinated Aδ-fibers
definitions_glossary.large_fiber_neuropathy: Damage to large myelinated fibers causing numbness, ataxia, weakness
definitions_glossary.autonomic_neuropathy: Damage to autonomic fibers causing orthostatic hypotension, GI dysfunction
definitions_glossary.NCS: Nerve conduction studies; measures velocity and amplitude of nerve signals
definitions_glossary.EMG: Electromyography; assesses muscle denervation and reinnervation
definitions_glossary.IENFD: Intraepidermal nerve fiber density; measured on skin biopsy for small fiber neuropathy
definitions_glossary.Charcot_Marie_Tooth: Most common hereditary neuropathy; demyelinating or axonal subtypes
definitions_glossary.CIDP: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy; treatable immune-mediated neuropathy

pathophysiology.mechanism: Damage to peripheral nerve axons and/or myelin from metabolic, toxic, inflammatory, or genetic causes

small_fiber.fibers_affected: Aδ (cold, pinprick), C (warm, dull pain, autonomic)

by_distribution.non_length_dependent: Patchy, asymmetric; suggests vasculitis, multifocal motor neuropathy

demyelinating.NCS_findings: Slowed conduction velocities, conduction block, temporal dispersion

clinical_assessment: History: sensory symptoms, weakness pattern, autonomic complaints, timeline
Exam: sensory modalities, reflexes, strength, gait

findings.demyelinating: Slow velocities (<80% normal), prolonged distal latencies, conduction block

specialized_testing.skin_biopsy: Gold standard for small fiber neuropathy (IENFD)
specialized_testing.lumbar_puncture: If demyelinating (CIDP: elevated protein, albuminocytologic dissociation)

expanded_workup.indications: If initial workup negative or clinical features suggest specific cause

differential_diagnosis: Myelopathy (upper motor neuron signs, bladder dysfunction)
Motor neuron disease (weakness without sensory symptoms)

treat_underlying_cause.diabetes: Optimize glycemic control to prevent progression

definition.@value: Dysfunction of peripheral nerves causing sensory, motor, and/or autonomic symptoms, classified by fiber type, distribution, and pathophysiology

scopeNote.@value: Covers classification, workup, and treatment of peripheral neuropathies with emphasis on identifying treatable causes

learning_objectives: Classify peripheral neuropathy by fiber type, distribution, and pathophysiology
Perform systematic workup to identify treatable causes
Interpret NCS/EMG to distinguish axonal from demyelinating neuropathy
Recognize small fiber neuropathy and its diagnostic approach
clinical_pearls: Diabetes + prediabetes cause ~50% of neuropathies - always check HbA1c
Demyelinating pattern (slow velocities) = think treatable causes (CIDP, GBS)
Normal NCS does NOT rule out neuropathy - may be small fiber (needs skin biopsy)
B12 deficiency: check MMA (sensitive); may have neurologic symptoms before anemia
Gabapentin and pregabalin: adjust for renal function
common_misconceptions: Neuropathy is always diabetic - 25% remain idiopathic even after workup
Normal NCS rules out neuropathy - small fiber neuropathy has normal NCS
Neuropathic pain needs opioids - first-line is gabapentinoids, SNRIs, TCAs
